column1: Kenosha () is a city in and the county seat of Kenosha County
column2: Wisconsin
column3: United States. Kenosha is on the southwestern shore of Lake Michigan. With an estimated population of 99
column4: 944 as of 1 July 2019
column5: it is the fourth-largest city in Wisconsin and the fourth-largest city on Lake Michigan. Although closer to Milwaukee
column6: the city is part of the United States Census Bureau's Chicago combined statistical area (CSA) and metropolitan statistical area.

column1: The Potawatomi originally named the area Kenozia (also transcribed ginoozhe
column2: kinoje) "place of the pike"
column3: while the early Ojibwa name is reported as Masu-kinoja "trout (pike) come all at once". These refer to the annual spawning of trout
column4: in which thousands of fish entered the rivers from Lake Michigan
column5: providing food for the coming months.

column1: Early archaeological sites have been discovered in the Kenosha vicinity; the discoverer of two sites believes they antedate the Clovis culture
column2: making them contemporaneous with the Wisconsin glaciation. Paleo-Indians settled in the area at least 13
column3: 500 years ago.The land was ceded by the Potawatomi in 1833
column4: when they sold the last of their land in Illinois and Wisconsin to the United States. They had hoped to protect their land claims by fighting alongside the US in the Black Hawk War of 1832
column5: but growing poverty forced them to sell in exchange for territory in Iowa and economic investments in schools and agriculture.The first European settlers
column6: part of the Western Emigration Company
column7: arrived immediately afterward
column13: who sought to purchase enough land for a town. Thwarted in Milwaukee and Racine
column14: the group arrived at Pike Creek on 6 June 1835
column15: building log houses and later homes of frame
column17: and brick. The first school and churches followed

column26: adapted from the Chippewa word kinoje (pike or pickerel).A prototype steam car was built in Kenosha by the Sullivan-Becker engineering firm in 1900. Two years later
column29: began production of the Rambler runabout. In 1902
column30: Rambler and Oldsmobile were the first cars to employ mass-production techniques. The 1903 Rambler was also the first US-built production automobile to use a steering wheel
column31: rather than the then-common tiller-controlled steering. Auto executive Charles W. Nash purchased Jeffery in 1916 and the new company became Nash Motors.

The town argued that industrial development would jeopardize the town's residential nature. The court found the annexation proper
column12: with no illicit bribes or improper conduct by the city.

column1: Kenosha is in southeastern Wisconsin at 42°34′56″N 87°50′44″W (42.582220
column2: -87.845624). It is bordered by Lake Michigan to the east
column3: the Town of Somers to the north
column4: the village of Bristol to the west
column5: and the village of Pleasant Prairie to the south. Kenosha's passenger train station is the last stop on Chicago's Union Pacific North Metra Line. Kenosha is 32 miles south of Milwaukee and 49 miles north of Chicago.

column4: 26.93 square miles (69.75 km2) is land and 0.10 square miles (0.26 km2) is water.

column1: Kenosha has a humid continental climate (Köppen Dfb
column2: bordering on Dfa) with warm summers and cold winters. The record high is 105 °F (41 °C)
column3: set in July 2012. The record low is −31 °F (−35 °C) set in January 1985.

column1: The mayor of Kenosha is John Martin Antaramian
column2: the longest-serving chief executive in the city's history over four terms between 1992 and 2008. Antaramian was re-elected on April 5
column3: 2016.Kenosha is represented by Bryan Steil (R) in the United States House of Representatives
column4: and by Ron Johnson (R) and Tammy Baldwin (D) in the United States Senate. Robert Wirch (D) represents Kenosha in the Wisconsin State Senate
column5: and Tip McGuire (D) and Tod Ohnstad (D) represent Kenosha in the Wisconsin State Assembly.

column2: decades ago a bustling hub of manufacturing
column3: is today a bedroom community because of the ease of access to the Chicago-Milwaukee corridor. According to county statistics
column4: 49% of Kenosha's workforce commutes outside of Kenosha County to their positions. Many travel northward towards Milwaukee or south into the Chicago area. The 2016 Kenosha County Out-Commuter Analysis
column5: underwritten by the Kenosha Area Business Alliance (www.kaba.org) and an adjunct to the coincidental Labor Analysis of Kenosha County
column6: found that Kenosha's "out-commuters most likely work for positions in healthcare
column7: manufacturing
column8: professional/scientific and technical services. The majority of occupations included management
column10: and office/administrative support position" and that 73 percent of out-commuters have a bachelor's degree or a higher level of education.A June 2009 study by the Milken Institute reported that Kenosha placed in the national top-50 high-tech economies.

column1: Snap-on Tools world headquarters and Jockey International corporate headquarters are in Kenosha. Kenosha has a number of light industrial and distribution companies in outlying business parks.

The Kenosha HarborMarket is a European-style Farmer's Market held mid-May through mid-October on Second Avenue bisected by the 56th Street boulevard streetcar line. It hosts stalls with local food products and artisans' creations. In winter
column2: the market moves indoors to the lobby of the 1927 Rhode Center of the Arts.

Kenosha has been served by rail service to and from Chicago since May 19

column2: the Kenosha Public Museum
column3: the Civil War Museum and the Dinosaur Discovery Museum
column4: and the Kenosha Historical Center are Smithsonian Institution affiliates.Completed in 2001
column5: the Kenosha Public Museum is on the Lake Michigan shoreline. Its main exhibit is a prehistoric woolly mammoth skeleton uncovered in western Kenosha in 1992. Cut-marks on its bones indicate that the animals were butchered by humans using stone tools. Carbon dating indicates their age to be 12
column6: 500 radiocarbon years old or 14
column7: 500 calendar years old
column8: one thousand radiocarbon years earlier than the previously-accepted presence of humans in the Americas. The museum also displays other ice age and fine art exhibits.The Kenosha History Center is in the 1917 city water treatment plant on Simmons Island adjoining the 1866 Kenosha Light Station. It showcases the history of Kenosha from the time of Native American settlements and the first European settlements to the present day. The 1906 Kenosha North Pier Light is nearby.

column1: Kenosha has 8 miles (13 km) of Lake Michigan shoreline frontage
column2: nearly all of which is public. The city has 74 municipal parks
column3: totaling 781.52 acres (3.1627 km2).Kenosha's Washington Park includes the oldest operating velodrome in the United States (opened in 1927) at Washington Bowl. The Kenosha Velodrome Association sponsors American Track Cycling sanctioned races and training sessions at the "Bowl" throughout the summer. Races are held on Tuesday evenings from mid-May through August. Free seating is available on the inside of the track
column4: and on important race days concessions are available.
